reviewText:
For such a cheap price at  release i.e. 80% off the usual Â£3.99, I had more fun playing  this Tower Defense  (TD) game  than I've had playing  a lot of games I've paid 20 times as much for.   Defend Your Life is  a  typical TD game with the usual  tower purchases, for example  upgradeable cannons and   tesla towers,  as well as other towers that  slow units down or toss grenades, plus there are special towers such as  those that give you extra oxygen.  Oxygen is the currency in game  which  allows you to purchase  more towers and  upgrades, plus  at the end of each  level you are awarded  tablets and  diamonds, both of which can be spent  either on  upgrading your tower  defenses or on special  upgrades that can only be used once to  top up  other  defenses that  usually take time to recover such as the electric shock , bomb or adrenaline.

The theme of this  TD game is  biological, with a human body  being attacked by viruses.  Each level gradually takes you further into the body.   You can set the speed up to four times the normal speed  and/or  select from three different difficulties.  Even at full price  I think Defend Your Life is  a bargain.   I reckon most  TD fans    will enjoy this game and it's also an  excellent  introduction   for those new to the genre. The easy mode is relatively easy to beat.  I played   through several levels  with no losses. The harder levels  give less currency to buy the various upgrades and   the speed of  the viruses  are increased, plus you get less oxygen currency to start with.



With 22 different enenies,  all with different strengths and weaknesses, for example the flu virus  divides into two weaker flu viruses  when it  is  killed  and the Nicotinic unit disappears when  first hit and is immune from attack while invisible, at least from the tower defenses. You can still damage  these with bombs and electric shocks.

There's a tips and tricks section as well as an encyclopedia that  gives you  information  about each building, for example  the Tesla tower  does more damage  for each shot  than any other  tower, but takes a longer  time to recharge.  There are some nice little touches like the defensive towers that  when activated  create little  beings that    don't do actual damage, but block the path of incoming  viruses.  When damaged they  recover  fairly quickly. If destroyed   new ones will replace them before the next wave.  You can  start  the next wave early by clicking on the warning symbol that pops up near the place where the viruses  first appear. The quicker you do this, the more oxygen is added to your total, giving you more currency to  buy or upgrade towers.

The 20 achievements  for this game are  relatively easy to attain, so long as you can survive the waves of viruses.  You can see a video of game play HERE. I highly recommend this game

A neat little Tower Defence let down by a few technical issues.
Verdict - 6.7/10

Gameplay - 7/10:
So firstly, when it comes to Tower-Defence (TDs) games you've got 3 types, there are the TDs that give you free will over where you can place Towers so you can create your own path (And sometimes HP bars for the Towers), there's the TDs where you have a pre-built path but you can choose where you place your towers next to the path, and then the TDs like Defend Your Life; where you have a pre-built path and pre-built locations to place the Towers, now all of them are good in their own way - preferably I like either complete freewill (Like DesktopTD) or just a pre-built path (Like BloonsTD) but the latter does cause you think more tactically at times as well. As I said, Defend Your Life is the 3rd one - pre-built path and pre-built Tower locations - you get 4 choices of towers and each of those 4 are separated into 2 more options, equalling 8 unique towers to build, fortunately each type of Tower comes with it's own special use making them all very different to eachother - and then of course you get the A-Typical upgrades you can do to make them stronger. You get attacked by different types of enemies which come in waves, each with their own purpose, like your fast but low HP enemies, the tanks and the invisible ones - all very basic. You can get Heroes, which although very awkward to control (Because of the 'Mobile Friendly' aspect of the game) are pretty cool to use, they level up as they get kills which allows you to upgrade them slightly each level up and allows you to fix any holes you may have in your defence. Then there's the 'out-of-game' upgrades you can do which just give little basic buffs here and there, like a little bit more money from creeps - you obtain coins to buy these by completing the levels in Easy/Medium/Hard.


Level Design - 6/10:
All the levels are based in the human body with 17 levels to run through. As I said, the game has a pre-built path and pre-built Tower locations, so you're almost forced to complete the level how it wants you to complete it, every single level I have managed to fill up every single Tower location... I felt that it made the game feel a bit 'limited' at times. In addition, on the earlier levels, and up until about half-way the game limits you to what upgrades you can buy for your towers - I have no idea why but once again, this makes the game feel limited - this is remains the case even if you progress through the game and get better upgrades...


Graphics - 7/10:
As I said, it's set in the human body so you can expect that the graphics to look like a cartoon human body - and they do. There's really nothing more to be said there, they look alright... Nothing special but feel free to decide for yourself from the screenshots and the gameplay video I have on it. As you upgrade a Tower it also changes aesthetically as well, it's a nice touch and all the upgrades make the Towers look like they have in fact, been upgraded. Unfortunately - and this is a big unfortunately... - the game has some hideous black borders at either side of the screen, something is clearly wrong with the resolution and it's not going wide screen... It's somewhat frustrating and hard to look past when you first start playing the game but as time goes on you get used to it. Other than that I feel almost inclined to mention that this game feels (and probably is) a mobile port, or at least developed with mobile in mind - think what you like on that, I personally feel a bit let down by it.



Overall - 6.7/10:
This game is pretty fun, unfortunately it's let down by a few technical issues such as the black borders and the fact that it was clearly made for mobile. Overall, if you like Tower-Defence games like this then chances are that you'll like this one too.

reviewText:
===// TL;DR Version //===

A decent but rather generic TD on the cheap.


===// Thorough Version //===

It's a recommended buy only if you're looking for a TD fix at a cheap price.
At the moment, when I write this review, it's 80% off.
Otherwise, there's nothing new compared to others in the swathe of TD games on Steam.

If you're looking for something new in terms of mechanics, look elsewhere.

The graphics isn't something to write home about; obvious mobile port is obvious.
The assets are well-drawn, detracting this game from the rest of the run-of-the-mill TD games.
Kinda reminds me of Worms.

It's based on Unity, with the usual Unity launcher and a maximum resolution of...1024x768?
I'm guessing the supported resolutions depend on the max vertical resolution of your display/monitor, which mine is 1366x768 since I'm on a laptop.
It does, however, seem to support multi-display, as in you can decide on which monitor you'd want this game to be displayed in via the Unity launcher.

There are (limited) global upgrades that affects towers' attack & range, tower sell value, specials' effectiveness, and in-level currency-related like how many starting oxygen per level or how much you get per mob kill.
These upgrades are bought using 'tablets', which you can get from finishing a level.
Each level holds a maximum of 7 tablets, which is divided to 3 at Easy, 2 at Medium, and 2 at Hard.
The tablets are finite, but you can easily 'sell' upgrades if you want to put the tablets into other upgrades that you want more.

The specials?
It basically breaks down to the basic three.
A bomb (AoE nuke), electric shock (global nuke), and adrenaline (AoE tower buff).
Yes, that's it.
Specials have infinite usage, though...limited only by their cooldowns.

The in-level currency is oxygen, and the in-game one is crystal.
Oxygen is what you use in a level to build towers.
Crystal is, I'm just guessing here, effectively what you'd buy with real money in the mobile version.
Crystals are used to buy boosters, which either adds oxygen, adds life, adds an extra of your strongest unit, resets all specials' cooldown, and global adrenaline.

Yep, typical freemium boosters.

The Encyclopedia is probably the most dodgy part of the game.
The Enemy details is in-game, but when you click for Tower details, the game opens up your browser to load the related webpage on the game's website.
Tips & Tricks is no different from Tower details.
Others is basically other games made by the game studio, and yes, acts the same way as Tower details.

Keep in mind that this game is a 430-ish MB download and 660-ish MB installed, so I don't really get the technical reason as for why they couldn't just cram everything locally in the Encyclopedia.

My conclusion?
Please refer to the TL;DR section at the top of this review. ;)

This game was reviewed using a code sent by the developer.
Defend Your Life is a cute little Tower Defence game with an interesting take on things. The whole game takes place in the human body, as you work your way around the body, you encounter plenty of different enemies with some really interesting abilities.

Another issue I encountered was in the later games when your screen is full of defence towers, was the horrendously bad fps drops, they were so bad at times, that it caused me to lose the level.  I would also of liked to have seen an options menu included to be able to change a couple of options such as windows mode, resolution etc. without having to exit the game altogether.

I did like how the game sort of prompts you to go back and get replay previous missions for extra points (tablets in this game), as it is pretty much impossible to progress at some points without going back to farm extra tablets to upgrade your abilities and towers.

Hopefully the technical issues can be ironed out, and if they can, then Defend Your Life is an excellent tower defence title, I will still recommend it now, because after all, I played it for almost four hours and still had a really good experience.

Overall, this is a thoroughly uninspiring and generic title with little to recommend it.

The game does import some of the awkward touch mechanics from mobile.  Unfortunately playing it on an actual touch screen like mine just doesn't really work all that well.  Instead you use a mouse and deal with input lag.

reviewText:
I would recommend this game at the discounted price of $1, and maybe at the normal $5. Although I wouldn't consider myself a veteran of TD games, I have played a few, and nothing about this game really stands out to me. It's cute, charming, good for a few hours of fun; but it wasn't anything that I couldn't walk away from, and now that I've stopped playing it, I don't really have any wish to continue.

I bought it primarily because I thought a TD game based off of the human immune system would be really cool. I was expecting a game where I could control all sorts of white blood cells to kill foreign viruses and bacteria. However, the game really doesn't follow this theme very well. For starters, your arsenal towers consist of the tesla (which is literally a metallic tower with an orb that fires electrical pulses), the cannon (again, literally a cannon resembling a tank or a machine gun), and the bomber (which fires literal cannon balls). Now, the cannon balls do visible damage to your body on the map, but this doesn't affect the game whatsoever. It's just an aesthetic effect. I think that's a real shame; it wouldn't have been very difficult to incorporate some kind of health meter for the body. When our immune systems fend off invading microbes, we do damage to our own cells as well, and that can lead to a lot of problems. So it wouldn't be inaccurate at all to impose on players the need to balance killing the infecting virus and bacteria without doing too much damage to the body. The currency in the game is oxygen, which is generated by a windmill. And there is a vitamin factory (which provides a boost to your melee towers), but it looks like some tower you'd see in a space station or some alien colony. You can even employ a hero such as the Hulk or a Lumberjack to run around inside your blood vessels.

The worst part of it is that the enemies are all legitimate viruses and bacteria, and the path they're traveling through is the blood vessels. So the overall effect is that you're inside your body, there are viruses and bacteria circulating through your system, and you're blowing them up with machine guns. And let's not forget the Lumberjack--inside your blood vessel--sawing his way through everything. There is such an odd disynchrony between the towers and the enemies, and it makes no sense. It just doesn't work at all. If you're thinking of buying this game because you, too, are allured by the whole human physiology aspect, prepare to be disappointed.

I believe that there are 17 levels in total, in different areas of the human body (lungs, stomach, kidneys, intestines, etc). I've already played through 7 or 8, and I'm still not fully done the tutorial, i.e. there are still features and upgrades I have yet to unlock. This should also speak for the length of the game (my playtime of 2.2 hours is accurate). The background art is well drawn, and does reflect the different parts of the body well; but the different maps are all very similar and I stopped paying attention to them at about the third or fourth level. The soundtrack is unremarkable, and I can remember nothing I want to say about it. The selection of towers is pitiful (I've already described every unit you can build in the game except one). And one thing that really annoyed me is that the level limitations don't change regardless of your difficulty setting. So, level one, easy: you obviously don't have all your towers or upgrades. That's fine. But once you advance in the game and go back to play level one on medium or hard, you still have only the same towers and upgrades as you did in the easy setting. Nothing you unlocked later on in the game is available to you. This greatly annoyed me, and makes it very difficult to win the more advanced levels. Again, I will say that I'm no TD veteran, so perhaps this would pose no challenge to you; but I do believe that players should have access to everything they've unlocked through their progress. For me, at least, it destroys replayability.

This game also has Steam pop ups for achievement progression. Not only that, but there are progression notifications for several achievements at once. So once you kill 100 viruses, expect a pop up that tells you you are 100/1000 to earning the first achievement, 100/2000 to earning the second, and 100/4000 to earning the third. The notifications convienently block access to some very important buttons, and if you get more than three at once, the entire game screen blacks out until the pop ups disappear. I don't feel like disabling my achievement notifications for one game. Devs, please fix this.

I can't speak for how well the game runs. I have a brand new 2015 laptop, so if I can't run a game like this, I don't expect that anyone would be able to. And, then again, considering how basic this game is, there really shouldn't be performance issues.

As I said in the beginning, I do recommend it if you can get it on sale. It's certainly not a polished game, but it's still a functional TD at heart once you get past all the inconsistencies and how generic it is. If you're looking for a break from other games, give this a try.

reviewText: This is a tower defense game, and in that regard, the game is good, but doesn't have any particular aspect that separates it from it's competitors. The concept seems fun: you are the commander of a human body immunity system, and you have to defend it in various levels, each in a different organ or muscle. The threats represent real life diseases such as angina, flu, cold, nichotin, cholestor, stonekid and even cancer. But when you play it, you'll quickly forget about all that, and it's just another tower defense game. But it's a good one. There's 18 levels each with 3 difficulties, but in practice they mostly play differently, so you have about 50 levels that feel different, even with the same layout. Each enemy type has different characteristics, and will require a different strategy. And there's plenty of tower types to build and upgrade, and they all play differently. There's also a hero that you can command, and other small upgrades to buy. Even if it's nothing new, there's plenty of content here to check. On another note, this game will no longer be patched, despite some bugs still present. But the game is completely playable, and i haven't had any real issues with it that prevented me from enjoying it. If you're worried, none of achievements are broken.
